item.title: Pope Leo Surprises St. Peter’s Crowd Before Christmas Eve Mass
item.description: Pope Leo XIV greeted the soggy faithful in St. Peter’s Square in both English and Italian and apologized that there wasn’t enough room in the basilica for them all.

item.title: With Airspace Closed, a Lonely Christmas for Many Venezuelans
item.description: The holidays usually bring home huge numbers from the Venezuelan diaspora. But this year, after international airlines halted almost all service, many people are spending Christmas alone and on edge.

item.title: Why the Right Is Boycotting Havaianas Flip-Flops
item.description: For decades, Havaianas flip-flops have been a beloved global symbol of Brazilian culture, worn by millions of people each day. They are now ensnared in a political fight.

item.title: ‘Carol of the Bells’ Once Filled the Air Here. Now It’s Only Bombs.
item.description: Mykola Leontovych, the Ukrainian composer of the famed festive song, lived in the eastern city of Pokrovsk. Months of Russian assaults have erased most tributes to his life there.

item.title: After Suffering in Israeli Prison, a Gaza Detainee Comes Home to More Pain
item.description: Haitham Salem spent 11 months held by Israel without charge and said he endured beatings and abuse. He was released as part of the cease-fire deal, longing to return to his family.

item.title: Prospect for Premier Returns to Bangladesh After 17 Years in Exile
item.description: Tarique Rahman, who had managed his party’s political affairs from Britain, is back in his country to campaign in elections.

item.title: ​North Korea Unveils the Completed Hull of What It Calls a Nuclear Submarine
item.description: The debut followed the North’s first test of a new surface-to-air missile and the arrival of a U.S. nuclear-powered attack sub for a port call in South Korea.

item.title: What Parents in China See in A.I. Toys
item.description: A video of a child crying over her broken A.I. chatbot stirred up conversation in China, with some viewers questioning whether the gadgets are good for children. But the girl’s father says it’s more than a toy; it’s a family member.

item.title: Why China, a One-Party State, Is Backing Elections in This Country
item.description: The vote in Myanmar, widely seen as a sham, is a bid for legitimacy by the military government. It is also a way for Beijing to exert its influence there.

item.title: Why Russia Is Likely to Reject the New US-Ukrainian Peace Plan
item.description: The first draft essentially called for Ukraine’s surrender. The revised version includes the security guarantees Kyiv wants to prevent future Russian aggression.

item.title: The Truce Is 2 Months Old. So Why Have Hundreds of Gazans Been Killed?
item.description: Since the cease-fire took effect, Israel says it has targeted only militants. But death can come for Gazans while on a family outing or sleeping in a tent.

item.title: Peng Peiyun, 95, Dies; Official Renounced China’s One-Child Policy
item.description: She was given the “hardest job under heaven”: upholding birth limits enforced by often brutal local officials. She came to support softening the policy, then abolishing it.

item.title: Honduras Declares Nasry Asfura, Trump Ally, Winner of Presidential Election
item.description: Nasry Asfura was endorsed by President Trump in a contentious election. His opponent, Salvador Nasralla, said he would not accept the results.

item.title: Australian State Passes ‘Extraordinary’ Gun and Protest Laws After Bondi Attack
item.description: While the new restrictions on firearms have broad support, new police powers to crack down on some protests were criticized as limits on civil liberties.

item.title: Trump’s Tanker Crackdown Paralyzes Venezuelan Oil Exports
item.description: Oil exports, the country’s financial lifeblood, have plummeted after the United States took action against three ships that have been used to carry its crude.

item.title: After the Assad Regime’s Fall, His Enforcers Are Lying Low and Living Large
item.description: A Times investigation into the whereabouts of top Syrian officials who fled after the regime’s fall shows many remain free — shielded by wealth and accommodating host nations.

item.title: Assad, Ousted Syrian Ruler, Leads Life of Luxury in Russia
item.description: Bashar al-Assad’s long, brutal reign ended swiftly, but he and his close circle have had a soft landing in Russia.

item.title: Zelensky Open to Pulling Back Troops in Eastern Ukraine to Reach Peace Deal With Russia
item.description: The offer was the closest Mr. Zelensky has come to addressing the thorny territorial disputes in Donetsk that have repeatedly derailed peace talks.

item.title: The Strange Case of the Russian Snickers in U.K. Convenience Shops
item.description: The Russian-labeled candy bars are a reminder of how difficult it is to completely disconnect a major economy from the global flow of goods.

item.title: Here’s What Is in the 20-Point Peace Plan for Ukraine
item.description: The blueprint covers a broad range of issues, including territory, security guarantees and postwar reconstruction. But Russia has indicated little willingness to end the war.

item.title: Blast Kills Three in Moscow Near Site of General’s Car Bombing
item.description: Two police officers died in the explosion, the authorities said. Earlier this week a car bomb killed a military commander in the same area of Russia’s capital.

item.title: The Deposed Assad Henchmen Plotting to Retake Syria
item.description: Hacked communications and a social media analysis reveal how former regime leaders are trying to arm fighters and exert influence as far away as Washington.

item.title: China Is Shifting Its Nuclear Forces to Swifter Footing, Pentagon Says
item.description: The country’s production of nuclear warheads has slowed, but its missiles may be poised to strike back fast in case of an attack, an annual assessment found.

item.title: A Vintage Kabul Cinema Finally Falls to Taliban Bulldozers
item.description: Built during a cosmopolitan era in the 1960s, the Ariana closed when the Taliban took power, but it was still standing. Now it’s making way for a shopping mall.

item.title: Thailand, Attacking Cambodia, Says Its Target Is the Scam Industry
item.description: Thai warplanes have bombed compounds where people are forced to defraud others online. Rights activists say trafficking victims’ lives are at risk.

item.title: Dating ChatGPT
item.description: The bot has been marketed as a general-purpose tool that can write code, summarize documents and give advice. But can it be a good boyfriend?

item.title: Libyan Military’s Chief of Staff and 4 Others Are Killed in Plane Crash in Turkey
item.description: The internationally recognized government of Libya confirmed the deaths of Lt. Gen. Mohamed Ali Ahmed al-Haddad, the army chief of general staff, and other officers flying home after a meeting in Turkey.

item.title: After Bondi Massacre, a Moment of Unity. Then, Bitter Partisanship.
item.description: The political point scoring that has erupted after the terror attack last week is unusual in Australia, where leaders tend to unite after catastrophes.

item.title: France Fails to Adopt a Budget by Year’s End. Again.
item.description: French lawmakers passed a special law on Tuesday to avoid a shutdown until a budget is adopted. Negotiations will resume in January.

item.title: Ukraine Withdraws From Eastern Town, Complicating Negotiating Stance
item.description: The town of Siversk had served as a stronghold in the portion of eastern Donetsk still under Ukrainian control. Moscow wants Kyiv to surrender the town as part of a peace deal.

item.title: Greta Thunberg Arrested at U.K. Protest Supporting Palestine Action Prisoners
item.description: The Swedish activist Greta Thunberg was arrested after holding a sign that the police said showed support for the group, which Britain banned this year.

item.title: Yemen’s Warring Sides Agree to Largest Prisoner Swap in a Decade of Fighting
item.description: The Houthi rebels and the internationally recognized government plan to exchange about 2,900 detainees, a rare humanitarian win at a time of deepening political stalemate.

item.title: Italian Artisans Add Figurines of Donald Trump to Nativity Scenes
item.description: For generations, Italian craftspeople have built scenes depicting Jesus’ birth, sometimes including figures of celebrities. This year, some are adding statuettes of President Trump.

item.title: Trump Tariffs Threaten Canadian Holiday Sales
item.description: Small businesses across Canada have lost out on sales because of the trade war, and many worry about their future.

item.title: German Leaders, Undercutting the Far Right, Are Leaning on the Far Left
item.description: Germany’s centrist establishment has long scorned the far left, but it is increasingly reliant on leftists to outmaneuver the far right in crucial votes in Parliament.

item.title: Two New Banksy Murals Appear in London
item.description: Two new London murals, widely attributed to the mysterious street artist, combine seasonal themes with what appears to be social commentary on rising child homelessness in Britain.

item.title: China Delays Plans for Mass Production of Self-Driving Cars After Accident
item.description: After years of planning for cars that would let drivers take their hands off the wheel and eyes off the road, China’s regulators have become more cautious.

item.title: Understanding Male Loneliness
item.description: Why is it harder for men to have intimate friendships into adulthood?

item.title: Trump Administration Oil Tanker Seizures Are Meant to Force Maduro Out, Officials Say
item.description: Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem said the ship seizures were meant to force Venezuela’s president Nicolás Maduro from power.

item.title: Trump Administration Orders Nearly 30 U.S. Ambassadors to Leave Their Posts
item.description: A union representing career diplomats said such a mass recall had never happened in the history of the U.S. Foreign Service.

item.title: Puzzle Designers Search for That ‘Satisfying Click’
item.description: For prizewinning puzzle creators, the devilish ideas are in the details.

item.title: Bondi Beach Gunmen Also Used Pipe Bombs in Attack, Police Say
item.description: But the explosives did not detonate, according to investigators, who also found a video of the two men training with firearms.

item.title: Lynching of a Hindu in Bangladesh Fans Fears of Rising Intolerance
item.description: Muslim co-workers accused the garment factory worker of blasphemy and dragged him into the street, where an angry mob murdered him.

item.title: Carney Names Financier Mark Wiseman as Canada’s U.S. Ambassador
item.description: Mark Wiseman has held high-profile roles in law, business consulting and finance, and will lead Canada’s efforts to reboot diplomatic relation with Washington at a critical moment.

item.title: U.K. Man and 5 Others Charged With Sexual Offenses Against His Wife
item.description: Philip Young, 49, is accused of drugging and raping the woman over a 13-year period. Five other men have been charged in the same case.

item.title: Russian General Is Killed in Car Bombing in Moscow
item.description: The attack appeared to be the latest targeted assassination of a senior military official inside Russia’s borders.

item.title: More Abducted Nigerian Children Are Released, Government Says
item.description: A spokesman for the Nigerian government said the “remaining” students taken from a Catholic school had been freed, but the local diocese said that only a “second batch” had been released.

item.title: What We Know About U.S. Interceptions of Oil Tankers in Venezuela
item.description: A Venezuela-bound vessel fled after rebuffing an attempt by the Coast Guard to seize it, the latest twist in the escalating U.S. pressure campaign against the Maduro government.

item.title: Angering Denmark, Trump Appoints Special Envoy to Greenland
item.description: President Trump, who has long said he wants to “get” the semiautonomous Danish territory, tapped Louisiana’s governor for the new position. Officials in Greenland and Denmark expressed outrage.

item.title: Christmas Is Back in Bethlehem, but Peace and Joy Have Yet to Arrive
item.description: Palestinian Christians are reviving their seasonal public celebrations, hoping to bring light and holiday spirit at the end of a gloomy year in the West Bank.

item.title: Sydney Shooting Suspects Met Muslim Leaders in Philippines, Officials Say
item.description: Intelligence authorities in the Philippines say the father and son apparently slipped out of Davao City during their monthlong stay, but details remain sketchy.

item.title: Russia Dismisses Reports of Progress in Ukraine Peace Talks
item.description: Proposals that emerged in recent negotiations with the United States were “rather unconstructive,” a Kremlin official said on Sunday.

item.title: As Trump Clings to Tariffs, His Argentine Ally Is Opening Up to Trade
item.description: President Javier Milei is eliminating barriers to what had been a closed-off economy, moving in the opposite direction of his main political ally, President Trump.

item.title: Jimmy Kimmel Will Deliver Britain’s ‘Alternative Christmas Message’
item.description: Mr. Kimmel will speak out against fascism and about the importance of free speech in the holiday address, according to a Channel 4 spokesman.

item.title: The Sibling Bond
item.description: Parenting is closely studied, but sibling relationships have gotten much less attention.

item.title: At Bondi Beach, Australians Mourn Shooting Victims
item.description: Thousands gathered a week after gunmen killed 15 people at a Hanukkah celebration. But hints of political divisions and anti-immigration rhetoric have emerged.

item.title: Élysée Palace Silver and Tableware Stolen by Steward, Prosecutors Say
item.description: In what prosecutors say was an inside job, copper pots, porcelain and Baccarat Champagne glasses were stolen from the inventory of the Élysée Palace.

item.title: 9 Killed in Mass Shooting at Tavern in South Africa
item.description: Around a dozen gunmen opened fire at bar patrons, the police said. A manhunt for the unknown assailants was underway.

item.title: ‘Orwellian Climate of Fear’: How China Cracks Down on Critics in the U.S.
item.description: The Chinese government once focused on political dissidents and exiled activists. Now, federal officials say, it is targeting artists in the United States whose creative protests test its tolerance.

item.title: Freed From a Belarus Prison, a Nobel Peace Laureate Experiences ‘Oxygen Intoxication’
item.description: Ales Bialiatski, who shared the Nobel in 2022, described long hours of backbreaking work and stints in solitary confinement.

item.title: When Something Goes Wrong With Your Flight, These People Take Charge
item.description: Inside a tornado-hardened office in Texas, 1,700 American Airlines employees manage the carrier’s operations, responding to bad weather, plane trouble and ailing passengers.

item.title: Guns from the United States are Pouring into Canada, Fueling a Spike in Gun Violence
item.description: The proliferation of illegal firearms from the United States has fueled a spike in gun violence in Canada, where most guns used in crimes are smuggled across the border.

item.title: The Pompidou Center Has Been Emptied of Its Art. We Watched It Happen.
item.description: The Pompidou Center is the place to see contemporary art in Paris. Or it was, until curators put its astonishing collection into storage.
